conclusion: The v-t graph represents the velocity-time relationship of a particle moving in a straight line, symmetric about a dashed line, and the particle passes through a certain position three times within the interval 0 to t1.
The v-t graph is symmetric about a vertical dashed line, with velocity decreasing to a minimum (negative value) and then increasing back to a positive value.
The symmetry of the graph implies that the time taken to reach the minimum velocity is equal to the time taken to return to the same velocity after reaching the minimum.
The particle undergoes a deceleration phase followed by an acceleration phase due to the symmetric nature of the graph.

For the particle to pass through a certain position three times, it must move away from the position, return to it, move away again, and finally return to it once more, involving a change in direction.
A change in direction is indicated by the velocity changing sign (crossing the time axis).
The first pass occurs when the particle starts from the initial position and moves forward as it decelerates.
The second pass occurs when the particle reaches a maximum displacement, reverses direction (velocity becomes negative), and returns to the initial position.

The third pass occurs when the particle continues in the opposite direction, reaches another maximum displacement, and then accelerates back towards the initial position, passing through it for the third time.
The graph shows the particle's velocity decreasing to a negative value, indicating a reversal of direction, and then increasing back to a positive value.
The particle's velocity is zero at the points where it changes direction, corresponding to the particle being at the maximum displacement from the initial position.
The particle's motion involves moving forward, reversing direction to move backward, and then reversing direction again to move forward, passing through the initial position three times.

The motion is characterized by the particle decelerating to a stop, accelerating in the opposite direction, and then decelerating and accelerating back to the initial direction, consistent with the symmetric v-t graph.
